Additionally, laboratory tests showed significant differences between the positive and negative RNAaemia groups, with magnesium and creatine phosphokinase levels proving to be better predictors of RNAaemia.

These findings suggest that SARS‐CoV‐2 RNAaemia may serve as an indicator of severe COVID-19 in children. Furthermore, the study proposes that magnesium and creatine phosphokinase could be considered as potential markers for estimating the presence of SARS‐CoV‐2 RNA in the blood.

Title: Bioinformatics and Immunoinformatics Revolutionize COVID-19 Vaccine Development

Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) has wreaked havoc across the globe, infecting over 109 million people and causing 2.4 million deaths as of February 17, 2021. With no approved treatments and conventional vaccines taking years to develop, scientists have turned to cutting-edge technologies to expedite the process. Bioinformatics and immunoinformatics, in particular, have emerged as powerful tools in the race to combat COVID-19.

In silico methods, such as bioinformatics, vaccinogenomics, immunoinformatics, structural biology, and molecular simulations, have revolutionized vaccine design. By leveraging these techniques, researchers can rapidly and precisely develop novel and effective vaccines and therapeutics. Two major strategies, reverse vaccinology and structural vaccinology, have emerged as game-changers in the field of immunoinformatics.

Reverse vaccinology involves analyzing the genomic sequence of the virus to identify potential vaccine targets. By studying the virus's genetic makeup, scientists can pinpoint specific proteins that can be targeted by the immune system. This approach has already yielded promising results in the development of the first immunoinformatics-based vaccine construct against SARS-CoV-2 in February 2020.

Structural vaccinology, on the other hand, focuses on understanding the three-dimensional structure of viral proteins. By elucidating the intricate details of these proteins, researchers can design vaccines that precisely mimic the virus's antigens, triggering a robust immune response. This approach holds great promise in developing next-generation COVID-19 vaccines.

The integration of immunoinformatics and bioinformatics into COVID-19 vaccine research has accelerated progress in the field. Researchers worldwide are utilizing these approaches to design innovative vaccines that can effectively combat the virus. The current scenario of immunoinformatics and bioinformatics in COVID-19 vaccine research is a testament to the power of these technologies in revolutionizing immunology.

Short and Mid-Term SARS-CoV-2 Antibody Response After Inactivated COVID-19 Vaccine in Hemodialysis and Kidney Transplant Patients

A recent study conducted on patients receiving kidney replacement therapy has shed light on the long-term antibody response to the inactivated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. The study included 50 hemodialysis patients, 64 kidney transplant recipients, and 41 healthy individuals as a control group. All participants received two doses of the CoronaVac vaccine.

After the administration of two doses, it was found that 44% of hemodialysis patients, 7.2% of kidney transplant recipients, and 58.5% of the healthy control group developed an anti-spike immunoglobulin G (IgG) level of ≥50 AU/ml. This indicates a robust antibody response in the control group compared to the kidney replacement therapy patients.

Furthermore, the study observed that the proportion of antibody titers peaked at the 3rd month after vaccination, with 86.5% of hemodialysis patients, 23% of kidney transplant recipients, and 97.6% of the control group showing positive antibody responses. However, at the 6th month, the antibody levels decreased significantly in most hemodialysis and control group participants, while kidney transplant recipients maintained their antibody response.

During the follow-up period, it was noted that kidney transplant recipients had a higher incidence of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) compared to the other groups. However, there were no cases requiring intensive care or resulting in death. Additionally, the study found a negative correlation between antibody seroconversion and age.

These findings highlight the importance of discussing vaccination strategies for immunocompromised patients, such as kidney transplant recipients. The study suggests considering a third dose of the vaccine, either with the same vaccine or a different one, to enhance the immune response in this vulnerable population.

Targeting complement activation in COVID-19

In a recent study published in the journal Blood, researchers have made a breakthrough in understanding the role of complement activation in COVID-19. The study reveals that spike proteins of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, responsible for causing COVID-19, activate the complement system through the alternative pathway (AP). This activation leads to immunopathology associated with the disease.

The researchers found that by inhibiting factor D or C5, two key components of the complement system, it is possible to mitigate the immunopathology caused by SARS-CoV-2. This discovery opens up new possibilities for targeted therapies in the treatment of COVID-19.

The complement system is an important part of our immune defense against pathogens. However, in the case of COVID-19, its activation can lead to harmful effects such as inflammation, tissue damage, and thrombosis. By specifically targeting complement activation, researchers hope to reduce these complications and improve patient outcomes.

Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms of complement activation in COVID-19 and to develop effective therapies. However, this study provides a promising starting point for future investigations and brings us one step closer to finding better treatments for this devastating disease.

Sequencing Confirms Delta Variant Emerged from India in Cargo Ship in China

A recent cluster of COVID-19 cases on a cargo ship in Zhoushan, China has been confirmed to be caused by the Delta variant of the virus, which originated in India. Out of the 20 crew members on the ship, 12 have tested positive for the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Genomic sequencing of four samples from the ship revealed that all of them belonged to the Delta branch of the virus, with several amino acid mutations in the spike protein.

This finding highlights the importance of genomic surveillance in tracking the spread of different variants of the virus. The Delta variant, known for its increased transmissibility and potential immune escape, has become a dominant variant worldwide. Understanding its presence and transmission patterns is crucial for effective control and prevention measures.

Effect of azithromycin and hydroxychloroquine in patients hospitalized with COVID‐19: Network meta‐analysis of randomized controlled trials

A recent network meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) aimed to determine the effectiveness of azithromycin (AZ) and hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) in improving clinical outcomes for patients hospitalized with COVID-19. The study analyzed a total of 10 RCTs, with participants ranging in age from 40.4 to 66.5 years.

The analysis found that neither AZ plus HCQ, AZ alone, nor HCQ alone had a significant effect on mortality rates among hospitalized COVID-19 patients. The odds ratios for mortality were 0.562 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.168–1.887) for AZ plus HCQ, 0.965 (95% CI: 0.865–1.077) for AZ alone, and 1.122 (95% CI: 0.995–1.266) for HCQ alone. Similarly, none of the treatments showed a significant benefit in reducing the use of mechanical ventilation.

The study concluded that based on the evidence from RCTs, AZ with or without HCQ did not have a significant effect on mortality or mechanical ventilation rates in hospitalized COVID-19 patients. However, the researchers emphasized the need for further research to explore therapeutic agents that can effectively reduce the severity and mortality of COVID-19.

Comparison of Saliva with Oral and Nasopharyngeal Swabs for SARS-CoV-2 Detection on Various Commercial and Laboratory-Developed Assays

A recent study conducted in Quebec, Canada, compared the accuracy of saliva samples with oral and nasopharyngeal swabs for the detection of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the virus responsible for COVID-19. The study aimed to determine if testing on saliva could be a viable alternative to the current method of combined oral and nasopharyngeal swab testing.

The study involved 320 tests from a total of 125 saliva and swab sample pairs. Various commercial and laboratory-developed tests were used to compare the results obtained from saliva and swab samples. The findings showed that all assays yielded similar sensitivity when saliva was compared to swabs, except for one laboratory-developed test which had a lower sensitivity.

Although there was a slight difference in the cycle threshold (∆C(t)) between saliva and swab samples, the overall concordance between the two methods was comparable. The study concluded that saliva testing could be associated with similar sensitivity to swab testing for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 using various assays.

This research suggests that testing on saliva could be a promising advancement in the fight against COVID-19. It offers several advantages over swab testing, including the elimination of discomfort caused by invasive sample collection and the potential to alleviate swab and transport media shortages. Further studies and validation are needed to fully establish the efficacy of saliva testing, but this research provides a strong foundation for its potential use in the future.

Healthcare Workers Show Stronger Antibody Response to BNT162b2 Vaccine Compared to CoronaVac

A recent study conducted in Turkey evaluated the antibody responses of healthcare workers (HCWs) who received a third booster dose of either the CoronaVac or BNT162b2 vaccine. The study aimed to assess the SARS‐CoV‐2 IgG antibody titers against the S1 subunit of the spike protein as a marker of the humoral response.

The results showed that out of the 136 HCWs who completed both serum collections, 103 (75.73%) chose the BNT162b2 vaccine, while 33 (24.26%) chose CoronaVac as their third booster dose. There was a significant difference in the SARS‐CoV‐2 IgG antibody titers between the two groups, with the BNT162b2 group showing much higher titers compared to the CoronaVac group (p < 0.001). The median SARS‐CoV‐2 IgG antibody titers in the BNT162b2 group were 17619.3 AU/ml, whereas in the CoronaVac group, it was 1153.0 AU/ml.

Furthermore, the study found that the third booster dose with BNT162b2 increased antibody titers in each participant by a mean of 162-fold, while CoronaVac only increased titers by 9-fold. However, it is worth noting that HCWs in the BNT162b2 group reported more frequent adverse events compared to those in the CoronaVac group (p < 0.001).

These findings suggest that the BNT162b2 vaccine elicits a stronger antibody response in healthcare workers compared to the CoronaVac vaccine. This information is crucial for understanding the effectiveness of different vaccines and making informed decisions regarding booster doses.

Clinical features and outcomes of four HIV patients with COVID‐19 in Wuhan, China

In a recent study conducted in Wuhan, China, researchers examined the clinical features and outcomes of four HIV patients who also contracted COVID-19. The study aimed to understand the potential risk factors and outcomes for individuals living with HIV/AIDS who are also infected with SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19.

The study found that the incidence proportion of COVID-19 in people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA) was comparable to the overall population incidence rate in Wuhan city. Out of the 11 COVID-19/AIDS patients identified, nine had relatively high CD4+ T lymphocyte count and undetectable HIV viral load. Additionally, ten of the patients were on antiretroviral therapy.

The study also revealed that PLWHA who were older, had low CD4+ T lymphocyte count, were infected with HIV through homosexual activity, and had been diagnosed with HIV for a longer period of time, were more likely to develop COVID-19. These findings suggest that individuals with worse immune responses may be at a higher risk of contracting COVID-19.

The researchers concluded that strategies to prevent SARS-CoV-2 infection among PLWHA with compromised immune responses are needed. As COVID-19 continues to spread globally, it is crucial to consider the specific vulnerabilities and risk factors faced by individuals living with HIV/AIDS.

Evaluation of the Relationship between KIM-1 and suPAR Levels and Clinical Severity in COVID-19 Patients: A Different Perspective on suPAR

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has become a global health crisis, and scientists are continuously working to understand the disease better. In a recent study, researchers aimed to investigate the levels of serum-soluble urokinase plasminogen activator receptor (suPAR) and kidney injury molecule 1 (KIM-1) in relation to the clinical course of COVID-19.

The study included 102 COVID-19 patients and a control group of 50 health workers. KIM-1 and suPAR levels were measured using specific assays. The researchers also analyzed other variables previously identified as prognostic indicators in COVID-19.

The results showed that patients with severe COVID-19 had significantly higher levels of KIM-1 compared to moderate patients. On the other hand, suPAR levels were lower in severe patients. This suggests that KIM-1 may play a crucial role in the endocytosis of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and could potentially be a target for future therapeutic interventions.

Furthermore, the study found that suPAR may have a role in the defense mechanism and fibrinolysis. Interestingly, low suPAR levels in severe patients were associated with a poor prognosis in the early stages of the disease.

This study provides valuable insights into the relationship between KIM-1 and suPAR levels and the clinical severity of COVID-19. It highlights the potential of KIM-1 as a therapeutic target and the importance of suPAR in the early prognosis of the disease.

SARS-CoV-2 Replicating in Nonprimate Mammalian Cells Shows Promise for COVID-19 Vaccines

Scientists have recently discovered a potential breakthrough in the development of COVID-19 vaccines. According to a minireview and proposals published in a reputable scientific journal, SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, replicating in nonprimate mammalian cells could have critical advantages for vaccine development.

The study explains that glycoproteins of enveloped viruses, like SARS-CoV-2, carry α-1,3-galactose (α-Gal) glycans, which can bind to anti-Gal antibodies found abundantly in humans. These antibodies have been protecting humans and their ancestors for millions of years by inhibiting the replication of various microbes carrying α-Gal glycans and aiding in their destruction.

Based on this knowledge, researchers propose that SARS-CoV-2 replicating in nonprimate mammalian cells, such as PK-15 cells, could be used as a live vaccine for COVID-19. The live vaccine's safety could be further enhanced through intramuscular inoculation, bypassing the fragile lungs. This approach has been successfully used with the live unattenuated adenovirus vaccine, which has been safely administered to US recruits for decades.

Additionally, the study suggests that the immune complexes formed by SARS-CoV-2 and anti-Gal antibodies could enhance the efficacy of COVID-19 vaccines, whether live or inactivated, carrying α-Gal glycans.

While these findings are promising, further experiments are needed to examine these novel vaccine strategies. If successful, they could have critical advantages in defeating the COVID-19 pandemic and preventing other viral infectious diseases.

Evaluation of human coronavirus OC43 and SARS‐COV‐2 in children with respiratory tract infection during the COVID‐19 pandemic

A recent study conducted at Children's Medical Center in Tehran, Iran aimed to evaluate the frequency and characteristics of Human Coronavirus OC43 (HCoV‐OC43) in children with respiratory symptoms during the COVID-19 pandemic. HCoV-OC43 is a Betacoronavirus responsible for mild respiratory symptoms, and its presentations are believed to resemble those of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS‐COV‐2).

The study included 117 patients with respiratory symptoms, and real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) methods were used to detect HCoV-OC43 and SARS‐COV‐2. The results showed that 23 patients (20%) tested positive for HCoV-OC43, while 25 patients (21%) tested positive for SARS‐COV‐2. Interestingly, two patients (2%) tested positive for both viruses, indicating a rate of coinfection.

Further analysis revealed significant differences between the two groups in terms of contact with family members with suspected or confirmed COVID-19, fever, edema, vomiting, abdominal complaints, and myalgia. Additionally, the median level of lymphocyte count was significantly lower in patients with HCoV-OC43 compared to those with SARS‐COV‐2 infection.

These findings suggest that HCoV-OC43 and SARS‐COV‐2 have a similar frequency in children with respiratory symptoms during the COVID-19 pandemic. The rate of coinfection observed in this study was 0.08. The researchers recommend further research on the cocirculation of these viruses in different regions and the need for more flexible test panel designs.

Impact of a Delayed Second Dose of COVID-19 Vaccines on Mortality and Hospitalization Rates

A recent study conducted in Hong Kong aimed to evaluate the impact of a delayed second dose of the mRNA vaccine (BNT162b2) and the inactivated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine (CoronaVac) on all-cause mortality, emergency department visits, and unscheduled hospitalizations. The study analyzed a retrospective cohort of individuals who had completed two doses of either vaccine between February and July 2021.

The results of the study showed that delaying the second dose of either vaccine beyond the recommended intervals did not have a significant association with all-cause mortality, emergency department visits, or unscheduled hospitalizations. The study included over 770,000 vaccine recipients, and the percentage of individuals who received the second dose beyond the recommended intervals was 3.8% for BNT162b2 and 28.5% for CoronaVac.

These findings suggest that regardless of the recommended or delayed schedule, it is important to administer the second dose of both vaccines to obtain better protection against infection and serious disease. However, the study also emphasizes the importance of following the manufacturer's recommended interval for vaccination until further studies support the benefits of delaying vaccination.

SARS‐CoV‐2 Infection Causes Pulmonary Shunt by Vasodilatation

A recent study conducted by researchers at a leading medical institution has shed light on the mechanism behind the significant hypoxemia observed in patients with COVID-19. The study, published in a prestigious medical journal, suggests that SARS‐CoV‐2 infection causes pulmonary shunt by vasodilatation.

Hypoxemia, a condition characterized by low levels of oxygen in the blood, has been a major concern in severe cases of COVID-19. While previous theories pointed towards microthrombosis and increased pulmonary dead space as the main contributors to hypoxemia, this new study challenges those notions.

Contrary to popular belief, the researchers found that dead spaces would not be sensitive to oxygen supplementation. Instead, they propose that a shunt mechanism by vasodilatation could explain the decubitus dependence in oxygenation observed in COVID-19 patients. This mechanism involves blood redistribution through the enlargement of pulmonary vessels.

To test their hypothesis, the researchers performed contrast-enhanced transthoracic echocardiography on a group of hospitalized COVID-19 patients. Out of the ten patients included in the study, seven showed evidence of intrapulmonary vascular dilatation (IPVD) and the presence of a shunt mechanism.

These findings have significant implications for the treatment of COVID-19 patients with hypoxemia. Unlike dead spaces, which are not responsive to oxygen supplementation, shunt mechanisms by vasodilatation could be more sensitive to such interventions. Understanding this mechanism could help healthcare professionals tailor their treatment strategies and improve patient outcomes.

Being pregnant in the COVID-19 pandemic: Effects on the placenta in all aspects

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), which originated in Wuhan, China, in late December, has been declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization. While the virus primarily affects the respiratory system, recent data suggests that it can also impact nonrespiratory organs. In particular, the placenta, which plays a crucial role in fetal development, carries a potential risk for the virus.

Studies have shown that COVID-19 can cause histopathological changes in the placenta. The presence of ACE2 and TMPRSS2, proteins involved in the virus's entry into cells, during placental development stages further highlights the potential vulnerability of the placenta to the virus. Although the vertical transmission of the virus is not yet fully understood, available data indicate that indirect effects on the fetus can occur.

This article aims to shed light on the various effects of COVID-19 on the placenta. By understanding these effects, healthcare professionals can better manage and support pregnant individuals during the pandemic.

Projected geographic disparities in healthcare worker absenteeism from COVID-19 school closures and the economic feasibility of child care subsidies: a simulation study

A recent simulation study has shed light on the potential impact of COVID-19 school closures on healthcare worker absenteeism and the economic feasibility of child care subsidies. The study, conducted at both national and county levels across the USA, aimed to provide a spatially granular analysis of the relationship between school closures and healthcare worker absenteeism.

The findings revealed that at the national level, the projected rate of unmet child care needs for healthcare worker households ranged from 7.4% to 8.7%. Additionally, school closures were estimated to result in a 7.6% reduction in fewer hospital beds and an 8.4% reduction in fewer intensive care unit (ICU) beds at peak demand. These estimates varied across states based on initial reproduction number estimates.

At the county level, there were substantial variations in projected unmet child care needs and school closure effects. Approximately 9.5% of healthcare worker households were projected to experience unmet child care needs, with a reduction of 5.2% in fewer hospital beds and 6.8% in fewer ICU beds at peak demand. The study also found significant positive associations between estimated levels of unmet child care needs and diabetes prevalence, county rurality, and race.

The study further estimated the costs of absenteeism and child care, revealing that providing child care to all healthcare workers with children would be less expensive for an estimated 76.3% to 96.8% of counties compared to bearing the costs of healthcare worker absenteeism during school closures.

In conclusion, while school closures are projected to reduce peak ICU and hospital demand, they could also disrupt healthcare systems through absenteeism, particularly in counties that are already vulnerable to COVID-19. The study suggests that implementing child care subsidies could help mitigate the trade-off between school closures and healthcare worker absenteeism.

Evaluation of a SARS‐CoV‐2 Antigen-Detecting Rapid Diagnostic Test as a Self-Test: Diagnostic Performance and Usability

A recent study conducted by researchers evaluated the diagnostic performance and usability of the COVID-VIRO® Antigen test as a self-test for the detection of SARS-CoV-2. The study included 239 asymptomatic and symptomatic patients and compared the results of the COVID-VIRO® Antigen test with the gold standard reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test.

The findings of the study showed that the COVID-VIRO® Antigen test, when combined with a nasal sampling method, had a sensitivity of 96.88% and a specificity of 100% compared to the RT-PCR test. This indicates that the test is highly accurate in detecting the presence of the virus. Additionally, a usability study involving 101 individuals revealed that 99% of the participants rated the instructions material as good, 98% executed the test procedure well, and 98% were able to correctly interpret the test results.

These results validate the relevance of the COVID-VIRO® Antigen test as a diagnostic tool using nasal specimens and demonstrate its usability in the general population. The high diagnostic performance and ease of use make it suitable for widespread utilization in controlling the spread of COVID-19.

Survival of SARS‐CoV‐2 in Artificial Seawater and on Inanimate Materials

A recent study conducted by researchers examined the stability of the SARS‐CoV‐2 virus in artificial seawater (ASW) and on the surface of various materials. The findings revealed important insights into the potential risk of virus spread through human contact with seafood and contaminated inanimate materials.

The study found that SARS‐CoV‐2 in ASW at 22℃ remained infectious for approximately 3 days, while at 4℃, the virus survived for more than 7 days. Notably, high titers of the virus could survive for more than 20 days in ASW at 4℃ and up to 7 days at 22℃. On stainless steel and plastic bag surfaces, the virus maintained infectivity for 3 days at 22℃, and on nonwoven fabric for 1 day. At 4℃, the virus remained infectious for 9 days on stainless steel and non‐woven fabric, and for 12 days on plastic bags.

These findings highlight the role of inanimate material surfaces as potential sources of infection and emphasize the importance of surface decontamination and disinfection. Understanding the stability of the virus in different environments can aid in implementing effective preventive measures to curb the spread of SARS‐CoV‐2.

Comparison of demographic and clinical characteristics of hospitalized COVID‐19 patients with severe/critical illness in the first wave versus the second wave

A recent study conducted by researchers aimed to compare the demographic and clinical characteristics of hospitalized COVID-19 patients with severe or critical illness in the first wave versus the second wave. The study included a total of 642 patients in the first wave and 1121 patients in the second wave who met the criteria for severe or critical illness according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

The results of the study showed that there was a higher proportion of patients with severe or critical illness in the second wave compared to the first wave (60.7% vs. 35.5%). However, there were no significant differences in terms of age, gender, and comorbidities between the two groups, except for chronic kidney disease.

Interestingly, the study found that the median serum C-reactive protein (CRP) levels were significantly higher in patients in the second wave compared to those in the first wave. Despite this, there were no significant differences in terms of intensive care unit admission and mortality rates between the two waves.

These findings suggest that although there may have been improvements in the management of COVID-19 patients with severe or critical illness in the second wave, the demographics and outcomes of hospitalized patients remained similar between the two waves. Further research is needed to understand the factors contributing to these findings and to continue improving the care of COVID-19 patients.

An exploratory study on the propagation of SARS‐CoV‐2 variants: Omicron is the most predominant variant

A recent study conducted on the propagation of SARS‐CoV‐2 variants has revealed that the Omicron variant is the most prevalent among others. As the virus evolves, it accumulates mutations, resulting in thousands of distinct variants. However, some variants have shown increased transmissibility and may affect illness pervasiveness. The study investigated SARS‐CoV‐2 variants and their prevalence in different countries.

According to the study, the top 25 countries where the Omicron variant is prevalent include the UK, US, Denmark, France, and Australia. The propagation rate of the Omicron variant was determined to be highest in the UK at 51%, followed by the US at 29%, Denmark at 26%, France at 15%, and Australia at 44%. These findings indicate that the Omicron variant is the most predominant among the others.

Additionally, the study analyzed the SARS‐CoV‐2 infection test rate in these five countries. It was found that viral testing should be increased in all five countries to determine the precise distribution of variants and aid governments in making policy decisions for public safety. The study suggests that limiting disease transmissions through vaccination and wearing masks in public places is the best strategy to prevent the emergence of new variants.

Estimating the Effect of Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions to Mitigate COVID-19 Spread in Saudi Arabia

A recent study conducted in Saudi Arabia has evaluated the effectiveness of non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) in controlling the spread of COVID-19. The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (KSA) implemented several NPIs, including travel restrictions, curfews, and the closure of public spaces, along with mandatory mask-wearing and physical distancing.

Using a spatial-explicit individual-based model, researchers simulated the spread of the virus in the KSA population. The results showed that NPIs such as mask-wearing, physical distancing, and contact tracing were highly effective in controlling the spread of the disease. Without these interventions, the KSA could have reported over 4.8 million cases by June 2021.

The study also highlighted the importance of implementing NPIs in schools and universities before resuming in-person education. It found that enforcing mask-wearing and physical distancing in educational institutions reduced cases, hospitalizations, and deaths by 25% and 50%, respectively.

Furthermore, the study emphasized the need for strict quarantine rules for international travelers to reduce the probability of outbreaks in the country. The researchers concluded that the KSA should continue to enforce NPIs until a significant portion of the population is vaccinated, in order to further reduce hospitalizations and deaths.

This study provides valuable insights into the effectiveness of NPIs in controlling the spread of COVID-19 and highlights the importance of adhering to these measures to protect public health.

Demographic, clinical, and laboratory features of COVID-19 in children: The role of mean platelet volume in predicting hospitalization and severity

A recent study conducted on children with COVID-19 aimed to investigate the various demographic, clinical, and laboratory features of the disease. The study also focused on the role of mean platelet volume (MPV) in predicting the prognosis and severity of the illness in children.

The study, which included 251 confirmed and 65 suspected COVID-19 cases, found that the majority of confirmed cases were mild (72.9%) or asymptomatic (19.1%). Only a small percentage of cases were classified as moderate (6.4%), severe (0.4%), or critically ill (1.2%).

The researchers observed that confirmed COVID-19 patients had lower mean values of white blood cell count, absolute neutrophil count, absolute lymphocyte count, platelet count, and hemoglobin levels compared to suspected cases. However, there was no significant difference in MPV levels between the two groups.

Furthermore, the study found that certain biomarkers such as C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, fibrinogen, and NT-pro-BNP were significantly lower in confirmed COVID-19 cases compared to suspected cases.

Among the confirmed cases, 21.9% of patients required hospitalization. The hospitalized patients had higher levels of MPV, white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, D-dimer, and NT-pro-BNP compared to outpatients.

The researchers also conducted a multivariate analysis to determine the factors associated with severe clinical symptoms. They found that lymphopenia (low lymphocyte count) and higher levels of fibrinogen were significantly associated with severe disease.

In conclusion, this study suggests that mean platelet volume (MPV) alone is not a reliable predictor of COVID-19 disease severity in children. However, when combined with other parameters such as white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, D-dimer, and NT-pro-BNP, MPV can be used to predict the need for hospitalization.

Lipemic Serum in COVID-19 Patients Reveals Potential Complications

A recent study conducted in Cincinnati, US, has shed light on the association between lipemic serum and severe acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). The study aimed to explore the impact of hypolipidemia on patient outcomes, focusing on specialized apolipoproteins apo A1 and apo B.

The researchers analyzed the lipid profiles of 50 COVID-19 patients and 30 sick controls presenting to the Emergency Department. The results showed that the COVID-19 cohort had significantly lower levels of apo A1 and higher apo B/apo A1 ratio compared to the control group. Furthermore, patients who developed severe AKI had significantly lower levels of LDL-C.

The study also found a correlation between hypolipidemia and various biomarkers associated with inflammation and impaired fibrinolysis. Low levels of LDL-C were particularly alarming, as they were predictive of renal deterioration in COVID-19 patients.

These findings highlight the importance of monitoring lipid profiles in COVID-19 patients and considering the potential complications associated with lipemic serum. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted interventions to mitigate the risk of AKI in this patient population.

SARS‐CoV‐2 Cold‐Chain Transmission: A Real Concern for COVID-19 Prevention and Control

In recent months, there have been growing concerns about the role of cold-chain transmission in the spread of the SARS‐CoV‐2 virus, which causes COVID-19. A study conducted in China has shed light on the characteristics, risks, and strategies associated with this mode of transmission.

The study found that low temperatures and certain humidity levels create an environment conducive to the survival and spread of the SARS‐CoV‐2 virus on cold-chain or frozen products and their outer packaging. This poses a significant risk, especially for individuals working in ports, cold storage facilities, or seafood markets.

Multiple localized outbreaks of COVID-19 have been reported in China, all linked to contaminated imported cold-chain products. These outbreaks have posed challenges to COVID-19 prevention and control efforts. To better understand the transmission dynamics, researchers analyzed the whole-genome sequencing and isolation of the SARS‐CoV‐2 virus from six confirmed cold-chain related outbreaks in China.

The findings from these outbreaks, as well as suspected cold-chain transmission in other countries, have provided valuable insights into the characteristics and mode of SARS‐CoV‐2 cold-chain transmission. It is crucial to recognize the underlying risks associated with this mode of transmission and implement preventive countermeasures.

This study emphasizes the need for strict adherence to hygiene and safety protocols in the handling and transportation of cold-chain products. It also highlights the importance of regular testing and monitoring of individuals working in high-risk environments. By understanding the risks and implementing appropriate strategies, we can effectively mitigate the spread of COVID-19 through cold-chain transmission.

Biphasic Anaphylaxis After COVID-19 Vaccine Raises Awareness of Potential Side Effects

In the midst of the global COVID-19 pandemic, vaccination has emerged as a crucial tool in combating the disease. However, as the number of people receiving vaccines increases, it is important to remain vigilant about potential side effects and complications. A recent case study highlights the occurrence of biphasic anaphylaxis, a severe allergic reaction, following the administration of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 mRNA vaccine.

The case involves a 30-year-old male who experienced a biphasic allergic reaction after receiving the vaccine. Biphasic anaphylaxis is characterized by an initial allergic reaction followed by a recurrence of symptoms after a period of time. While several reports of allergic reactions have been documented after the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, it is crucial to recognize the potential risk of anaphylaxis in select individuals and have appropriate measures in place to address adverse events.

This case serves as a reminder that even though COVID-19 vaccines are generally safe and effective, there can be rare instances of severe allergic reactions. Healthcare professionals should maintain a high index of suspicion for anaphylaxis and be prepared to administer epinephrine to prevent the development of a delayed biphasic reaction. By staying informed and vigilant, we can ensure the safe administration of COVID-19 vaccines and protect public health.

A Rapid and Cost-Effective Method for Genotyping SARS-CoV-2 Phylogenetic Clades

Scientists have developed a groundbreaking method for genotyping the circulating phylogenetic clades of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Tracing these clades is crucial for outbreak alerts and epidemiological surveillance. The traditional approach of high-throughput sequencing has proven to be costly, time-consuming, and labor-intensive, especially in low-income countries.

However, a team of researchers has proposed a rapid, simple, and cost-effective method called amplification refractory mutation system (ARMS)-based multiplex reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay. This method can identify six distinct phylogenetic clades: S, L, V, G, GH, and GR.

The multiplex PCR is designed in a mutually exclusive way to identify V-S and G-GH-GR clade variants separately. By including all five variants in the pentaplex assay and the triplex variants alongside either V or S clade mutations in the quadruplex assay, two separate subsets are created. This allows for a comprehensive analysis of the circulating clades.

To validate the method, the researchers tested it on 24 COVID-19-positive samples. The optimized conditions included a primer concentration of 0.2-0.6 µM, an annealing temperature of 56-60°C, and a complementary DNA concentration of 3-5 ng/µl. The presence of clade-featured mutations was further confirmed through targeted Sanger sequencing.

This multiplex ARMS-PCR assay offers a fast, low-cost alternative for genotyping SARS-CoV-2 phylogenetic clades. Its convenience and accuracy make it a valuable tool for researchers and public health officials in monitoring the spread and evolution of the virus.

High-Dose Corticosteroids May Not Improve Outcomes in Hospitalized COVID-19 Patients

A recent study conducted on hospitalized COVID-19 patients has shed light on the use of high-dose corticosteroids in improving outcomes. The study, which analyzed data from March 2020 to March 2021, compared the effects of standard dose steroids (less than 40 mg daily) versus high dose steroids (more than 40 mg daily) on various outcomes.

The findings revealed that patients who received high-dose corticosteroids had a higher unadjusted in-hospital mortality rate compared to those who received standard doses. Further analysis using inverse probability weighted regression adjustment confirmed this association, showing that high-dose corticosteroids were associated with higher odds of death. However, it is important to note that high-dose corticosteroids were linked to lower rates of acute kidney injury requiring hemodialysis.

These results suggest that higher doses of corticosteroids may not necessarily lead to better outcomes in COVID-19 patients. While corticosteroids have shown to decrease mortality in COVID-19, the optimal dosing remains a topic of debate. Further research is needed to fully understand the effects of different corticosteroid doses on COVID-19 outcomes.

COVID-19 Encephalopathy: A Rare Manifestation of SARS-CoV-2

Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the virus responsible for COVID-19, has been primarily associated with respiratory symptoms. However, recent reports have highlighted its potential to affect the central nervous system. In a case study, we present the unique case of a patient with a history of substance abuse who initially presented with suspected drug overdose. Despite treatment for substance withdrawal, the patient's encephalopathy persisted and was accompanied by choreiform movements.

Extensive investigations were conducted to identify the underlying cause, including metabolic, infectious, and rheumatologic workup. Surprisingly, the patient tested positive for COVID-19, leading to the suspicion of COVID-19 encephalopathy. Further confirmation was obtained through an MRI, which revealed multiple focal enhancing lesions primarily affecting the bilateral medial putamen and left cerebellum, along with subcortical lesions.

Prompt administration of glucocorticoids resulted in significant improvement in the patient's mental state and choreiform movements. While neurologic presentations associated with COVID-19 are increasingly being reported, encephalopathy with choreiform movements remains a rare manifestation. It is believed that this neurological complication may be due to direct viral invasion or autoimmune-mediated toxicity triggered by the initial viral infection.

This case highlights the importance of considering COVID-19 as a potential cause of encephalopathy, even in patients with a history of substance abuse. Early recognition and appropriate management can lead to favorable outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms underlying COVID-19-related neurological complications.

Recent Advances in Point-of-Care Testing for SARS-CoV-2

In a recent study, researchers have made significant progress in developing point-of-care testing (POCT) methods for the detection of the novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) caused by SARS-CoV-2. With the rapid spread of the virus worldwide, it has become crucial to have rapid testing and timely control of epidemic situations, especially when resources are limited.

Traditional laboratory-based nucleic acid detection methods have been effective but come with a long turnaround time and high cost. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop convenient and cost-effective methods for detecting COVID-19. This paper summarizes the advancements in POCT for SARS-CoV-2 detection, focusing on nucleic acid extraction, amplification, and detection methods.

One notable development is the introduction of a commercial real-time detection system that integrates all three steps of nucleic acid testing. This system not only provides accurate results but also addresses the key considerations for its effective use. The findings of this review aim to serve as a valuable reference for emergency response and rapid deployment of COVID-19 testing, as well as for other emerging infectious diseases.

Comparative Evaluation of Panbio and SD Biosensor Antigen Rapid Diagnostic Tests for COVID-19 Diagnosis

A recent study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic performance of two antigen rapid diagnostic tests (Ag-RDTs) for diagnosing severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. The study evaluated the Panbio and SD-Biosensor Ag-RDTs using 186 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) negative samples to assess specificity and 170 PCR positive samples to evaluate sensitivity.

The sensitivity of both assays was found to be 100% for samples with a cycle threshold (Ct) value of 20 or lower. For samples with a Ct value between 20 and 25, the sensitivity was 93.0% for Panbio and 95.3% for SD-Biosensor. Sensitivity decreased for samples with a Ct value between 25 and 30, with Panbio showing a sensitivity of 41.3% and SD-Biosensor showing a sensitivity of 52.2%. For samples with a Ct value of 30 or higher, Panbio had a sensitivity of 5.0% and SD-Biosensor had a sensitivity of 17.5%.

The study also evaluated sensitivity based on the number of days post onset of symptoms (d.p.o.). Within seven d.p.o., Panbio had a sensitivity of 87.7% and SD-Biosensor had a sensitivity of 90.4%. However, sensitivity notably decreased after seven d.p.o.

Agreement with PCR was excellent for samples with a high viral load (Ct ≤ 25), with Panbio showing 98.9% agreement and SD-Biosensor showing 97.4% agreement. The agreement between the two Ag-RDTs was also excellent, with a kappa score of 0.882.

In conclusion, the Panbio and SD-Biosensor Ag-RDTs showed excellent agreement and diagnostic performance for samples with high viral loads (Ct ≤ 25) or samples within seven d.p.o. These findings highlight the importance of considering the Ct value and days post onset of symptoms when interpreting the results of antigen rapid diagnostic tests for COVID-19.

Variants of concern responsible for SARS‐CoV‐2 vaccine breakthrough infections from India

Emerging reports of SARS‐CoV‐2 breakthrough infections have raised concerns about the efficacy of vaccines. A recent study conducted in India sheds light on the genomic analysis of isolates from breakthrough infections following vaccination with AZD1222/Covishield and BBV152/Covaxin. The study found that the variants of concern B.1.617.2 and B.1.1.7, which were responsible for the surge in cases in Delhi during April-May 2021, were the predominant lineages among breakthrough infections.

The findings highlight the importance of methodical genomic surveillance in determining the effectiveness of vaccines. By analyzing the genetic makeup of the virus in breakthrough cases, researchers can identify any potential variants that may evade the immune response triggered by vaccination. This information can then be used to inform vaccine development and public health strategies.

Understanding the role of variants of concern in breakthrough infections is crucial for managing the ongoing pandemic. It emphasizes the need for continued monitoring and adaptation of vaccination strategies to stay ahead of the evolving virus. By staying informed and updated on the latest scientific research, we can make informed decisions to protect ourselves and our communities.

Effectiveness and safety of Ivermectin in COVID‐19 patients: A prospective study at a safety‐net hospital

A recent study conducted at a safety-net hospital aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of Ivermectin in hospitalized patients with COVID-19. The study included a total of 286 patients with COVID-19, who were divided into two groups - one receiving Ivermectin in addition to usual clinical care, and the other receiving only usual clinical care.

The results of the study showed that the length of hospital stay was higher in the Ivermectin group compared to the control group. However, this difference did not maintain significance when adjusted for confounders. On the other hand, the control group had a longer length of intensive care unit (ICU) stay and duration of mechanical ventilation. Importantly, there was no significant difference in mortality rates between the two groups.

These findings suggest that while Ivermectin may not have a significant impact on the length of hospital stay or mortality rates in COVID-19 patients, it may have some potential benefits in terms of reducing the need for intensive care and mechanical ventilation. Further research is needed to fully understand the effectiveness and safety of Ivermectin in treating COVID-19.

Prior immunosuppressive therapy is associated with mortality in COVID-19 patients: A retrospective study of 835 patients

A recent retrospective study conducted at a single academic medical center has shed light on the impact of prior immunosuppressive therapy on COVID-19 patients. The study, which included 835 patients diagnosed with COVID-19 between March 10, 2020, and October 13, 2020, aimed to investigate the severity of the disease in individuals who had been prescribed immunosuppressive medications.

The findings of the study revealed that patients who had received immunosuppressive therapy prior to their COVID-19 diagnosis had a higher mortality rate compared to those who had not received such treatment. Specifically, 30% of patients on immunosuppressive therapy succumbed to the disease, while the mortality rate among patients not on immunosuppressive therapy was 17%. This difference was found to be statistically significant, with an odds ratio of 2.1.

Furthermore, the study also highlighted that laboratory markers of inflammation were consistently elevated in both patients on immunosuppressive therapy and those not on such treatment who unfortunately passed away. However, it was observed that lymphocytes and neutrophils were decreased in COVID-19 patients on immunosuppressive therapy, regardless of their outcome.

These findings emphasize the importance of closely monitoring and providing adequate supportive care for individuals who are immunosuppressed and diagnosed with COVID-19. The study provides valuable insights into the severity of the disease in this specific patient population and underscores the need for tailored approaches to their treatment and management.

Clinical Characteristics of 4499 COVID‐19 Patients in Africa: A Meta‐Analysis

A recent meta-analysis conducted on the clinical characteristics of COVID-19 patients in Africa has shed light on the impact of the virus on the continent. The study, which evaluated evidence from previous studies available in six databases, included a total of 4499 COVID-19 patients.

The findings of the meta-analysis revealed that 68.8% of the infected patients were male. The most common symptoms reported by the patients were fever (42.8%), cough (33.3%), headache (11.3%), and breathing problems (16.8%). Other minor occurring symptoms included diarrhea (7.5%) and rhinorrhea (9.4%).

Furthermore, the study found that the fatality rate among COVID-19 patients in Africa was 5.6%. Importantly, there was no publication bias observed in the study, indicating the reliability of the findings.

This study provides the first comprehensive description and analysis of the clinical characteristics of COVID-19 patients in Africa. The identification of common symptoms such as fever, cough, and breathing problems can aid in early detection and prompt medical intervention, ultimately improving patient outcomes.

Title: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Reveals Limited Efficacy of Treatment Options for SARS-CoV-2 Infection

In a recent systematic review and meta-analysis, researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various treatment options for severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. The study included 29 studies with a total of 5207 patients, focusing on therapeutic interventions in patients aged 18 years and above.

The primary outcome of the analysis was all-cause mortality, while secondary outcomes included rates of mechanical ventilation, viral clearance, adverse events, discharge, and progression to severe disease. The researchers calculated pooled rates and odds ratios (OR) to assess the overall effectiveness of the interventions.

The findings revealed that the pooled all-cause mortality in the intervention arm was 12.8%. Notably, studies using hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) as an intervention showed significantly higher mortality rates (OR: 1.36) compared to other treatment options. Furthermore, the HCQ subgroup also experienced higher rates of adverse events (OR: 3.88).

However, there was no significant difference in other secondary outcomes among the various treatment options. The study concluded by emphasizing the need for well-designed randomized clinical trials to further investigate the efficacy and safety profiles of different therapeutic interventions for SARS-CoV-2.

Dynamic changes of functional fitness, antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 and immunological indicators within 1 year after discharge in Chinese health care workers with severe COVID-19: a cohort study

A recent cohort study conducted in Hubei Province, China, has shed light on the health consequences faced by health care workers (HCWs) who had severe COVID-19 infections. The study aimed to investigate the health outcomes of HCWs after their discharge from the hospital. The participants underwent three physical examinations, including tests of functional fitness, antibodies to SARS-CoV-2, and immunological indicators, at different time points after discharge.

The study found that a significant proportion of HCWs with severe COVID-19 did not fully recover their functional fitness even after one year of discharge. However, there was a noticeable improvement in muscle strength, flexibility, and agility/dynamic balance in the follow-up visits. The third physical examination revealed higher levels of IgM antibodies and median titres of IgM and IgG antibodies compared to the first examination. Additionally, a considerable number of HCWs still had elevated levels of IL-6 and TNF-α, and some showed decreased relative numbers of CD3(+) T cells and CD4(+) T cells.

These findings highlight the importance of active intervention to aid the recovery of HCWs with severe COVID-19. The study emphasizes the need for continuous monitoring of functional fitness, antibodies to SARS-CoV-2, and immunological indicators even after one year of discharge. By understanding the long-term health consequences, appropriate measures can be taken to support the well-being of HCWs who have battled severe COVID-19 infections.

Oxidative Stress and Decreased Nrf2 Level in Pediatric Patients with COVID-19

A recent study conducted on pediatric patients with COVID-19 infection has shed light on the impact of the virus on oxidative stress and the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor (Nrf2). The study aimed to investigate the change in Nrf2 levels, which plays a critical role in protecting cells against oxidative stress, and its relationship with oxidative balance.

The study included 40 children with confirmed COVID-19 infection and 35 healthy children as a control group. The researchers compared the two groups in terms of Nrf2 levels, total oxidant status (TOS), total antioxidant status (TAS), and oxidative stress index (OSI). They also took into account clinical findings such as fever, cough, shortness of breath, contact history, and demographic data.

The findings of the study revealed that the pediatric patients with COVID-19 had significantly lower Nrf2 values and TAS levels compared to the control group (p < 0.001). Additionally, the TOS level and OSI were significantly higher in the children with COVID-19. The researchers also observed a significant positive correlation between Nrf2 and TAS, indicating that as Nrf2 levels increased, so did TAS levels. Conversely, there was a significant negative correlation between Nrf2 and TOS and OSI, suggesting that higher Nrf2 levels were associated with lower TOS and OSI levels.

These results indicate that COVID-19 infection in pediatric patients leads to a decrease in Nrf2 levels. This decrease in Nrf2 may explain the tissue damage caused by the virus, as it is known that Nrf2 plays a crucial role in protecting cells against oxidative stress. Further research is needed to explore potential therapeutic interventions targeting Nrf2 to mitigate the effects of COVID-19.

SARS‐CoV‐2 RNA detected in stool samples from acute gastroenteritis cases in Brazil

Researchers in Brazil have made a groundbreaking discovery regarding the detection of the SARS‐CoV‐2 virus in stool samples from patients with acute gastroenteritis (AGE) symptoms. The study, conducted from January to July 2020, analyzed 121 stool samples using quantitative reverse‐transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). The results revealed that 27.5% of the samples received during the epidemic period tested positive for SARS‐CoV‐2 RNA.

It is important to note that no infectious viruses were observed in Vero E6 cells, indicating that the virus detected in the stool samples may not be capable of causing active infection. However, this finding highlights the potential for SARS‐CoV‐2 to be present in the gastrointestinal tract, even in the absence of respiratory symptoms.

This research provides valuable insights into the transmission and detection of SARS‐CoV‐2, shedding light on the potential role of the gastrointestinal system in the spread of the virus. Further studies are needed to fully understand the implications of these findings and their impact on public health strategies.

SARS‐CoV‐2 Variant with Mutations in N Gene Affecting Detection by Widely Used PCR Primers

In a recent study conducted in Southern Finland, researchers discovered a variant of the SARS‐CoV‐2 virus that has mutations in the N gene, which affect its detection by widely used PCR primers. This finding has important implications for diagnostic testing and the accuracy of COVID-19 case identification.

The researchers observed that two commercial PCR analyses failed to recognize the N gene target in coronavirus disease 2019 cases. However, these analyses were able to detect the other target gene of the virus. Upon further investigation, the complete viral genome sequence analysis revealed several mutations in the N gene that were not previously documented in public databases.

Specifically, the researchers identified a short 3 bp deletion and three subsequent single nucleotide polymorphisms in the N gene, precisely at the site where an early published and widely used N gene‐based PCR primer is located. This explains the negative results in the N gene PCR. The variant strain was later identified as a member of the B.1.1.318 Pango lineage, initially found in Nigerian samples collected in January 2021.

It is important to note that these mutations in the N gene can cause diagnostic resistance, potentially leading to underdiagnosis of the virus. Additionally, this variant strain shares the S gene E484K mutation with the Beta variant, which has been linked to impaired vaccine protection. However, it differs from the Beta variant in other ways, such as deletions in the N gene region.

These findings highlight the need for careful inspection of virus variants and continuous monitoring of their impact on diagnostic testing and vaccine efficacy. Understanding the genetic changes in the virus is crucial for developing effective strategies to combat the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

Clinical Characteristics and Risk Factors of Mild-to-Moderate COVID-19 Patients with False-Negative SARS-CoV-2 Nucleic Acid

A recent study conducted on mild-to-moderate COVID-19 patients has shed light on the clinical characteristics and risk factors associated with false-negative results in nucleic acid tests for the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The research, which enrolled 19 cases of false-negative patients and 31 cases of nucleic acid positive patients, analyzed their epidemiological, clinical, laboratory examination data, and imaging characteristics.

The findings revealed that the false-negative group had a lower percentage of epidemiological exposure (52.6% vs. 83.9%; P = .025) and less chest discomfort (5.3% vs. 32.3%; P = .035) compared to the nucleic acid positive group. Additionally, the false-negative patients experienced a faster recovery time (10 [8, 13] vs. 15 [11, 18.5] days; P = .005). The study also observed that the false-negative group had a lower number of involved lung lobes (2 [1, 2.5] vs. 3 [2, 4] days; P = .004) and a lighter lung damage severity score (3 [2.5, 4.5] vs. 5 [4, 9] days; P = .007).

These findings suggest that the absence of epidemiological exposure may be a potential risk factor for false-negative nucleic acid results. It is crucial to note the significance of false-negative cases of COVID-19, as they pose a risk of viral transmission without positive test results. Moreover, these cases exhibit milder clinical manifestations and a lower history of epidemiological exposure. This study emphasizes the importance of understanding the limitations and potential risks associated with false-negative results in COVID-19 testing.

Role of genetic variants and host polymorphisms on COVID‐19: From viral entrance mechanisms to immunological reactions

New research suggests that genetic factors may play a significant role in the severity and manifestation of COVID-19. The wide range of disease presentation and severity seen across different ethnic backgrounds and geographical locations has raised questions about the underlying factors contributing to these variations. In addition to population density, gender, age, and comorbidities such as diabetes and hypertension, genetic factors are believed to influence susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Scientists are currently investigating the genetic variants involved in the pathologic processes of the virus, including its entrance into cells, antiviral immunity, and inflammatory response. Understanding these genetic polymorphisms could have significant implications for our understanding of SARS-CoV-2 pathogenicity and the development of personalized medical care based on population investigation.

While knowledge regarding the pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still in its infancy, this research highlights the importance of considering genetic factors when managing the disease in populations. By identifying at-risk individuals and comprehending the variations in disease severity, healthcare professionals can tailor their approach to effectively combat the virus.

Positive Externalities of an Epidemic: The Case of the Coronavirus (COVID-19) in China

Amidst the global economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, China's relentless efforts to contain and find a cure for the virus have unexpectedly led to some positive outcomes. This article aims to shed light on the beneficial effects resulting from the public policies and strategies implemented in China to combat and ultimately eradicate COVID-19.

One significant positive externality of the pandemic is the opportunity it has provided for testing futuristic technologies. China has been at the forefront of utilizing advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence, big data analytics, and robotics to enhance disease surveillance, contact tracing, and patient care. These technological advancements not only aid in the fight against COVID-19 but also pave the way for future innovations in healthcare and disease prevention.

Another positive spillover from China's efforts is the reduction in the spread of false information. The government's strict measures to control the pandemic have included cracking down on misinformation and rumors. This has resulted in a more informed public, better equipped to make decisions based on accurate and reliable information. By curbing the dissemination of false information, China has contributed to the global fight against misinformation surrounding the pandemic.

Furthermore, the policies enacted to control COVID-19 have inadvertently led to a reduction in pollution levels. With strict lockdown measures and reduced industrial activities, China has experienced a significant decrease in air pollution and carbon emissions. This temporary respite for the environment highlights the potential for sustainable practices and serves as a wake-up call for the world to prioritize environmental conservation in the post-pandemic era.

Lastly, China's response to the pandemic has included the provision of social safety nets for affected individuals and businesses. Measures such as financial assistance, job protection, and business support have helped mitigate the economic impact on vulnerable populations. These social safety nets not only provide immediate relief but also contribute to long-term resilience and recovery.

While the COVID-19 pandemic has undoubtedly caused immense global challenges, it is crucial to recognize the positive externalities that have emerged from China's response. The testing of futuristic technologies, reduction in false information, decrease in pollution, and implementation of social safety nets are all valuable lessons that can guide future policies and strategies in combating similar crises.

Early Clinical Factors Predicting the Development of Critical Disease in Japanese Patients with COVID-19: A Single-Center, Retrospective, Observational Study

A recent study conducted in Japan aimed to identify the factors that predict the progression of COVID-19 from mild to critical. The researchers retrospectively evaluated the risk factors for disease progression in Japanese patients with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19.

The study included 74 patients who were hospitalized between February 20, 2020, and June 10, 2020. Asymptomatic, non-Japanese, and pediatric patients were excluded from the analysis. The patients were divided into two groups: the stable group and the progression group, which consisted of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.

After comparing the clinical factors between the two groups, the researchers identified several significant risk factors for disease progression. An elevated level of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), a decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), lymphocytopenia (low lymphocyte count), and statin use were found to be associated with the progression of COVID-19 from mild to critical.

It is important to note that lymphocytopenia at admission was not found to be a significant risk factor in the Cox proportional hazards analysis. However, the study identified three candidate risk factors for progression to critical COVID-19 in adult Japanese patients: statin use, elevated LDH level, and decreased eGFR.

This study provides valuable insights into the early clinical factors that may help predict the development of critical disease in Japanese patients with COVID-19. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore potential interventions based on these risk factors.

SARS‐CoV‐2 Originated from Bats and Potentially Yak as Intermediate Host

A recent study conducted by a team of researchers aimed to investigate the evolutionary history and potential animal hosts of the SARS‐CoV‐2 virus, responsible for the current COVID-19 pandemic. The researchers analyzed 137 genomes of coronavirus strains from January 2019 to March 2020.

Their findings revealed that SARS‐CoV‐2 shares a high similarity with betacoronavirus isolates found in bats, specifically the HKU5-related strain from Pipistrellus abramus and the HKU4-related strain from Tylonycteris pachypus. Additionally, the researchers identified a yak betacoronavirus strain, YAK/HY24/CH/2017, as the closest match in the comparison of spike glycoprotein structures.

Interestingly, the yak betacoronavirus strain possesses unique features, suggesting the possibility of yak serving as an intermediate host for the transmission of SARS‐CoV‐2 to humans. These findings shed light on the potential origins of the virus and provide valuable insights for further research and prevention strategies.

Predicted Norovirus Resurgence in 2021-2022 Due to the Relaxation of Nonpharmaceutical Interventions Associated with COVID-19 Restrictions in England: A Mathematical Modelling Study

A recent mathematical modeling study conducted in England has predicted a potential resurgence of norovirus in the coming year. The study focused on the impact of the relaxation of nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) associated with COVID-19 restrictions on the incidence of norovirus.

The researchers used a mathematical model fitted to community incidence data to project the expected incidence of norovirus based on contact surveys conducted throughout 2020-2021. The results of the study indicate that susceptibility to norovirus infection has likely increased between March 2020 and mid-2021.

Depending on the assumptions made about future contact patterns, the study suggests that the incidence of norovirus could either be similar to pre-pandemic levels or potentially increase beyond what has been previously reported once the restrictions are lifted. If adult contact patterns return to 80% of pre-pandemic levels, the incidence of norovirus is expected to be similar to previous years. However, if contact patterns return to pre-pandemic levels, there is a possibility of the expected annual incidence being up to 2-fold larger than in a typical year.

The study also found that the age-specific incidence of norovirus is similar across all age groups. The researchers conclude that continued national surveillance for endemic diseases like norovirus will be crucial after the NPIs are lifted. This will allow healthcare services to adequately prepare for a potential increase in cases and hospital pressures beyond what is typically experienced.

Evaluation of predictors of severe‐moderate COVID‐19 infections at children: A review of 292 children

A recent study conducted on 292 children hospitalized due to COVID-19 aimed to identify the independent risk factors for estimating the severity of the disease in children. The study found that children with pre-existing comorbid conditions, such as obesity and asthma bronchiale, were more likely to experience a severe course of COVID-19. The presence of lymphopenia and hypoalbuminemia, as well as elevated levels of C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, and uric acid, were also detected in children with moderate to severe COVID-19 infections. The study concluded that high uric acid levels and lymphopenia were the strongest predictors of severe COVID-19 infections in children. These findings highlight the importance of considering pre-existing conditions and laboratory variables when assessing the severity of COVID-19 in children.

Should the world collaborate imminently to develop neglected live‐attenuated vaccines for COVID‐19?

The rapid spread of the Delta variant suggests that SARS‐CoV‐2 will likely be rampant for months or years and could claim millions of more lives. All the known vaccines cannot well defeat SARS‐CoV‐2 due to their limited efficacy and production efficiency, except for the neglected live‐attenuated vaccines (LAVs), which could have a much higher efficacy and much higher production efficiency than other vaccines. LAVs, like messiahs, have defeated far more pathogenic viruses than other vaccines in history, and most current human vaccines for viral diseases are safe LAVs. LAVs can block completely infection and transmission of relevant viruses and their variants. They can hence inhibit the emergence of vaccine‐escape and virulence‐enhancing variants and protect immunologically abnormal individuals better in general. The safety of COVID‐19 LAVs, which could save millions of more lives, can be solidly guaranteed through animal experiments and clinical trials. The safety of COVID‐19 LAVs could be greatly enhanced with intramuscular or oral administration, or administration along with humanized neutralizing monoclonal antibodies. Together, extensive global collaboration, which can greatly accelerate the development of safe COVID‐19 LAVs, is imminently needed.

Outcomes of COVID-19 Patients at Delhi Government Hospital Revealed

A recent study conducted at a tertiary care government hospital in Delhi, India has shed light on the outcomes of hospitalized COVID-19 patients. The study, which analyzed data from 10,314 laboratory-confirmed patients admitted between April and November 2020, found that 86.28% of patients were discharged after recovery, while 13.72% sadly succumbed to the disease.

The mean age of the hospitalized patients was 46.43 years, with a slight majority being male (58.50%). The study also revealed that increasing age was associated with higher odds of mortality in both genders. Interestingly, the mortality rate in female patients was lower compared to male patients, although elderly women had the highest odds of mortality.

The study also highlighted the possibility of delayed health seeking behavior among elderly women, possibly due to familial and social neglect. It was observed that mortality in COVID-19 patients often occurred early after admission, suggesting rapid deterioration or delayed reporting by patients. However, the overall statewide recovery rate has shown steady improvement since the onset of the pandemic.

This study provides valuable insights into the outcomes of hospitalized COVID-19 patients and emphasizes the importance of timely hospitalization to reduce the risk of complications and mortality. The findings also highlight the need for targeted interventions to address the specific challenges faced by elderly women in seeking timely healthcare.

Clinical Characteristics of Pediatric SARS-CoV-2 Infection and Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Kuwait

A recent study conducted at Jaber Alahmad Hospital in Kuwait aimed to understand the clinical characteristics of pediatric COVID-19 patients and estimate the duration of viral shedding. The study found that children generally have less severe disease compared to adults, with most infected children being asymptomatic.

During the study period from February 29th to April 30th, 2020, all SARS-CoV-2 infected patients between the ages of 1 month and 18 years, regardless of symptoms, were hospitalized at Jaber Alahmad Hospital. A total of 134 pediatric cases were identified, with 67.9% of them being asymptomatic.

The median age of the infected children was 8.8 years, and the majority (89.5%) were healthy. The most commonly reported symptoms were cough and fever. Among the symptomatic patients, the disease was mild, and mild pneumonia was observed in some cases.

The study also found that the duration of viral shedding, as measured by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positivity, was substantial in both symptomatic and asymptomatic patients. The median duration to PCR negativity was 15 days for symptomatic patients and 15.5 days for asymptomatic patients.

In conclusion, this study highlights the high prevalence of asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection in children and the mild nature of the disease in symptomatic cases. It also emphasizes the importance of understanding the duration of viral shedding in pediatric patients. These findings contribute to our understanding of COVID-19 in children and can help guide public health measures.

Atypical Bacterial Co-Infections Found Among COVID-19 Patients in India

A recent study conducted in an Indian tertiary hospital has revealed emerging evidence of co-infection with atypical bacteria among patients with COVID-19. The study focused on respiratory illnesses caused by bacteria such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, and Legionella pneumophila, which can exhibit similar symptoms and imaging features to COVID-19, leading to diagnostic challenges.

The researchers conducted a prospective study from June 2020 to January 2021, involving 194 patients with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19. These patients were also tested for atypical bacterial pathogens. The diagnosis of M. pneumoniae was made using a real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay and serology (IgM ELISA), while C. pneumoniae diagnosis relied on IgM serology. L. pneumophila diagnosis was based on PCR or urinary antigen testing.

Out of the 194 COVID-19 patients, 17 (8.8%) were diagnosed with co-infections of M. pneumoniae (10 cases) or C. pneumoniae (7 cases). The co-infection group exhibited more frequent symptoms such as confusion, headache, and bilateral infiltrate compared to patients with only SARS-CoV-2 infection. Additionally, patients with co-infections were more likely to develop acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), require ventilatory support, have a longer hospital stay, and experience a higher fatality rate compared to those with only SARS-CoV-2 infection.

This study highlights the importance of considering co-infection with atypical bacteria causing pneumonia in COVID-19 patients, depending on the clinical context. Timely identification of co-existing pathogens can enable targeted treatment and potentially prevent fatal outcomes in patients infected with SARS-CoV-2 during the ongoing pandemic.

T-Cell Responses to Omicron Spike Epitopes Remain Largely Protective after Booster Vaccination

A recent study has shed light on the T-cell responses to the Omicron variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The Omicron variant, which contains more than 30 mutations, has raised concerns about its ability to evade immune responses elicited by prior infection or vaccination. However, researchers have found that T-cell responses remain largely protective even after booster vaccination.

The study involved individuals who received the CoronaVac vaccine and underwent booster vaccination. The researchers stimulated peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from these individuals with peptides derived from the spike protein of the ancestral virus or the Omicron strain with mutations. They found that booster vaccination substantially enhanced T-cell activation in response to both the ancestral and Omicron epitopes, although the enhancement was slightly weakened by the Omicron mutations.

Interestingly, the researchers also observed that only specific mutations, such as G339D or N440K, significantly destabilized the T-cell response. However, more participants need to be evaluated to confirm these findings.

Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the impact of Omicron mutations on T-cell responses. It suggests that T-cell responses remain largely protective against the Omicron variant after booster vaccination, offering hope in the fight against the evolving virus.

Clinical Data Supports the Role of Hydroxychloroquine in COVID-19 Treatment

Recent clinical and biological data have shed light on the potential role of hydroxychloroquine (HCL) in the treatment of COVID-19. Studies have shown that HCL exhibits inhibitory effects on the NLRP3 inflammasome, a key player in the pathogenesis of respiratory diseases caused by SARS-CoV-2.

The NLRP3 inflammasome is a complex protein structure that triggers the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, leading to the development of severe respiratory complications in COVID-19 patients. By inhibiting the activity of the NLRP3 inflammasome, HCL may help mitigate the destructive inflammation associated with the disease.

Numerous clinical trials have been conducted to evaluate the efficacy of HCL in COVID-19 treatment. Preliminary results have shown promising outcomes, with patients experiencing reduced severity of symptoms and faster recovery rates. However, it is important to note that further research is still needed to fully understand the optimal dosage and treatment duration.

No SARS-CoV-2 Carriage Observed in Children Attending Daycare Centers during the Initial Weeks of the Epidemic in Belgium
